Well, when commentator Gillian Clark sits down at her holiday table, it's with a chef's perspective.
She offers us her insight into what makes a holiday and what makes family.
I come from a big family.
I'm the youngest of five, and my father, a twin, has eight brothers and sisters.
My mother has six aunts and uncles and several carloads of cousins.
You can imagine how crowded it gets around the holidays.
There's the annual gathering at Aunt Melba's house.
Football is on in the den and carols are sung at the out-of-tune piano in the basement.
Each year is as reassuringly familiar as the last, with the annual exchange of fruitcake.
It's amazing what a career in food service will do to one's perception of the holidays.
Like most chefs, I look at the calendar and circle the days with a groan.
They are the hardest days of the year and most of us dread the winter months, where the holidays pop up like the moles in that arcade game and staff disappear just as fast.
Turkeys roast all night and into the morning.
Bushels of chestnuts must be scored, roasted and peeled.
Is there a stainless steel pot big enough for 40 pounds of cranberries?
It's a stressful time.
In the professional kitchen, there's little time to think of pilgrims, Santa and goodwill toward man.
In the kitchens, cooking for holidays, we've let go of our holiday rituals.
Thanksgiving dinner one year was taken with the busboy, dishwasher and salad cook sitting on milk crates, our plates perched on our knees, huddled together in dry storage.
Then there was the Christmas Eve I stumbled into the Chinese restaurant after closing down my kitchen.
While I waited for my egg roll, the waiter pushed a bowl of soup in front of me and poured me a cup from the pot of green tea he was drinking.
It was a gesture of understanding and knowing what I might be giving up working this night and the next.
New Year's I've toasted midnight with people I've never seen out of uniform, and I had to fight the crowd to embrace the young dishwasher who kept my supply of clean pans coming.
In restaurants we call it a family meal when staff eats together.
We are a family with bonds forged over stress, panic and hard work.
Working long hours, some of us having left family behind to work two and three jobs, we've learned to find family and re-create our holiday rituals.
Commentator Gillian Clark runs the Colorado Kitchen restaurant in Washington, DC.

We all know that troops who see combat can suffer from emotional problems - anxiety, depression, post-traumatic stress.
Less attention, though, has been paid to the children of these soldiers.
And so, a group of researchers headed to a Marine base to study kids whose parents were deployed to Iraq or Afghanistan.
To talk about what they found, we're joined by our regular medical expert, Dr. Sydney Spiesel.
He's a pediatrician as well as a Yale Medical School professor.
Welcome back, Syd.
Thank you.
Nice to be here.
Now, these children, these were little kids, right?
Oh, yeah.
The kids who were studied were in the one-and-a-half years to five-year range.
In each case, it was only one parent deployed.
They all lived on the same Marine base, which was actually Portsmouth, Virginia.
They were all enrolled in a base-supplied childcare program, which allowed them to be studied more closely.
There was one atypical thing, by the way, which is that the deployments were shorter than one would expect.
The average was only three and a half months, and we know that many deployments are a year or a year-and-a-half or even longer than that.
And still, even though it was a short deployment, the researchers still saw negative consequences.
Yes, yeah.
The whole question of behavioral change was studied by having both parents and teachers fill out questionnaires about the child's behavior.
And these kids were compared with other kids on the same base.
The only difference is, the comparison kids didn't have a parent deployed to a combat zone.
And what were they measuring, what kinds of behavior?
Well, two kinds of behavior.
One were the internalizing behaviors, where kids turn stress and so forth inward, symptoms like anxiety and depression and withdrawal and complaints of physical symptoms like stomach aches.
The other kind were externalizing things, kids who became more aggressive and who had sort of poorer attention and maybe hyperactivity or who were breaking rules.
So, as you said, this was a group of one-and-a-half to five-year-old kids, and the most interesting result was with the older kids of that group, the three to five-year-olds?
Yes, the three to five-year-olds showed more of both kinds of behavioral problems, both the internalizing and the externalizing.
So, what are the possible reasons for that?
Well, there are a lot of possible reasons.
One, for example, might have been that the parent who was left behind, almost always the mom, was more distressed or depressed or anxious.
And the researchers were aware of that as an issue and did use some statistical tricks to subtract that.
We don't think that that was playing so much of a role.

Ludicrous.

I might make a reservation for some of the most sycophantic people around him.
